 Well, seeing as how you were about a year old or less during the first Gulf War, maybe you don't remember that after that Saddam was pretty powerless to threaten anyone. Right after there were uprisings that we encouraged, but did not support. Saddam crushed them (killed them). 
 
 Especially in 2003, after years of UN sanctions, Iraq was pretty lame.
 They could barely defend their homeland for a few weeks against invaders much less invade anyone themselves.
 
 Right before 9/11 both Condi and Powell made comments about "We've got him in a box." and "Saddam is no threat."

 I'm making fun of people who make the distinction between "lawful" and "unlawful" combatant to justify things like torture, etc.

I guess technically to the Americans who live their lives in little boxes and rarely stick their heads above the cardboard Saddam may not have been a threat. 
 To Americans being fired at, shot, down, and killed outside of Iraq by Iraqi made weapons (gee now we know why inspectors failed to find them) Saddam's legacy is the threat.
 To the Kurds, who are probably the most thankful; Saddam is no longer a threat because he mass murdered most of them (remind you of anyone else in history? like Hitler maybe)
 Ask also the former Iraqi soccer team what Saddam is to them; lose a game get tortured for months on end. 
 Did we really just want to let Saddam continue on his path of "good will"?
